pred:
A British Army officer, Scott Sears, has made history by becoming the youngest person to reach the South Pole solo and unsupported. The 27-year-old lieutenant, who is the brother-in-law of tennis star Andy Murray, completed his 702-mile journey in just 38 days, 12 days earlier than anticipated. Sears, from east London, faced extreme weather conditions, including 150mph winds and temperatures as low as -50 degrees Celsius. Despite the challenges, he managed to pull a sled carrying his supplies and equipment, and even crossed the most dangerous part of the journey, which is known for its crevasses, alone.

Sears, who was a tennis player before joining the Army, described hitting a wall just before reaching the pole on Christmas Eve. However, he managed to push through and reached his destination on Christmas Day. He raised over £33,500 for the Gurkha Welfare Trust to help rebuild schools in Nepal, which were destroyed in the 2015 earthquake.

Sears' achievement has been confirmed by the Guinness World Records, making him the youngest person to complete the solo and unsupported mission to the South Pole. He is currently waiting for a plane to take him back to civilization and is looking forward to taking a shower and having some food. His family, including Andy Murray and his mother Judy Murray, have congratulated him on his remarkable feat.
answers: While many people were unwrapping gifts on Christmas Day, the brother-in-law of tennis star Andy Murray was wrapping up a 700-mile, 38-day journey through brutally cold temps and blistering winds—and, he hopes, setting a world record. Scott Sears, 27, reached the South Pole on Monday, and he says he's the youngest person ever to do so solo, though Guinness has yet to offer its final seal of approval, the BBC notes. "MERRY CHRISTMAS FROM THE SOUTH POLE! Absolutely chuffed to pieces," he wrote on his blog, where he documented his unassisted adventure, which included temperatures of minus 58 degrees and wind gusts of up to 150mph. Sears said he was so tired when he finally took a rest after his trek that he fell asleep "within about 2 minutes of my head hitting the mat." Sears, whose sister, Kim, is married to the tennis star, describes a grueling expedition with icy, crevasse-marred terrain and an isolation made worse when the "iPod poltergeist" would occasionally strike, causing his music player to stop working. He says he "truly hit a wall" on Christmas Eve, where "everything was just saying 'no more, not one more step.'" But he devoured some dried meat, juice, and chocolate and pushed through, even hanging up his stinky socks as "makeshift stockings" for Santa that night. Sears' message from Andy Murray's mom once he arrived at his destination: "Well done Scott Sears." If Guinness confirms Sears' feat, he'll be three years younger than the previous record-holder, per the Telegraph. (Prince Harry drank champagne out of a prosthetic leg when he arrived at the South Pole.)

The escape was a surprise to prison officials, as Elliot was classified as a minimum-security inmate and was not considered a flight risk. The Michigan Department of Corrections is conducting an internal investigation into the escape.

"We will continue to work closely with our partners in Indiana to ensure the safety of our communities."

Michael David Elliot, 40, allegedly stole a woman's red jeep and abandoned it in the small town of Shipshewana, Indiana, this afternoon. Knowing Elliot "can go a lot of places in seven hours," police went door-to-door and had schools locked down before releasing students under a heavy police presence. But the driver kept going and led authorities on a 5-minute chase. Stop sticks disabled his tires in Kankakee Township; Elliot jumped out and tried to run but was arrested and booked. He was serving five life sentences for the murders of four people when he broke out of the Ionia Correctional Facility yesterday by slipping through a gap in the fencing system.

Mursi's opponents have been protesting against his rule since he was elected in June 2012, citing concerns over his Islamic agenda and his handling of the economy. Mursi's supporters, meanwhile, defended his actions and accused the opposition of trying to overthrow a democratically elected president. They argued that the opposition was using violence to undermine the democratic process and create instability in the country.

German prosecutors have indicted two former Nazi SS guards, aged 92 and 93, for their roles as accessories to murder while they served at the Stutthof concentration camp in Poland during World War II. The men, who have not been named, are currently under investigation for their involvement in the deaths of approximately 65,000 people, including Jews, at the camp. Prosecutors in Dortmund filed the indictments last week but only announced them on Wednesday due to the defendants' advanced age and the complexities of the case. Both men deny any knowledge of the killings and have not been arrested yet.

One of the survivors of the camp, Judith Meisel, from St. Louis Park, Minnesota, has provided crucial testimony to the German authorities. Meisel, now 88, was able to identify one of the accused men, Johann Rehbogen, as a teenage guard who taunted her and other female prisoners. Meisel's mother, Mina, died in the gas chamber at Stutthof in late 1944.

Under German law, Meisel could join the prosecution as a "co-plaintiff" in the case. This legal approach allows survivors to participate in the trial and share their experiences, providing valuable context and insight into the atrocities committed at the camp.

The indictments mark a significant development in the pursuit of justice for the victims of Stutthof, as many of the perpetrators are now elderly or have passed away. Since 2011, German authorities have been actively investigating and prosecuting former Nazi guards under the principle of "accessory liability," which holds individuals accountable for their role in the operation of concentration camps, even if they did not directly commit the murders.

The trial could provide a platform for survivors like Meisel to share their stories and seek closure, while also shedding light on the horrors of the Stutthof concentration camp and the broader history of the Holocaust.
answers: Judith Meisel says that when she was a teenager in the Stutthof concentration camp in western Poland, other prisoners told her: "Don't let us die without you mentioning what happened to us." The 88-year-old Minnesota resident has not forgotten: Her testimony helped German authorities indict two former guards from the camp where 65,000 people, including Meisel's mother, died, the Minneapolis Star Tribune reports. She identified one former guard, 94-year-old Johann Rehbogen, as the young SS officer who would taunt female prisoners as they undressed. Prosecutors say the men can't be tied to specific murders, but their work as guards made the killings possible. Meisel—who escaped along with her sister when inmates were sent on a "death march" away from the camp in 1945—says she is willing to relive her horrific experiences to help prosecutors. "This process of seeking answers and finding justice for my mother gives new meaning to my life," she says. The two former guards have been charged as accessories to murder, the AP reports. They deny any knowledge of killings at the camp, where thousands were starved to death or froze. Prosecutors say prisoners were also gassed to death, shot, and killed with lethal injections. Authorities say Meisel and several other Stutthof survivors in the US could be called as witnesses if the former guards are deemed healthy enough to stand trial. (A pendant found at the Sobibor camp helped reunite a family.)

Antarctic notothenioid fishes have evolved antifreeze proteins, known as antifreeze proteins (AFPs), to survive in the frigid waters. However, these AFPs come with a paradoxical cost: they not only prevent freezing but also inhibit melting, leading to the accumulation of ice within the fish's body. A team of researchers discovered this phenomenon while studying the coping mechanisms of notothenioid fishes in extremely cold conditions. They found that the AFPs not only prevent ice formation but also hinder ice melting, which could potentially be harmful to the fish.

The researchers investigated the impact of this ice accumulation on notothenioid fishes by examining temperature records from a high-latitude Antarctic fish habitat and conducting experiments in the lab. They found that the ice melting inhibition occurs both in vitro and in vivo, meaning that the ice persists inside the fish even during summer months when temperatures rise. This finding exposes a potential antagonistic pleiotropy, where the beneficial effect of AFPs in preventing freezing comes with the cost of lifelong ice accumulation.

The researchers emphasized that more research is needed to understand how notothenioid fishes eliminate internal ice and whether there are any mechanisms to mitigate the potential risks associated with ice accumulation. The study sheds light on the complex adaptations of Antarctic fishes to survive in extreme environments and the trade-offs that come with such adaptations.
answers: How do the fish that thrive in the waters around Antarctica prevent their blood from turning to ice? Turns out at least some of them don't. Scientists have long known that the group of fish species known as notothenioids have an antifreeze protein in their blood that prevents them from being frozen to death, but new research has revealed that the same protein keeps ice crystals in their veins, apparently permanently, UPI reports. The crystals melted at a few degrees above freezing, but the fish may spend their whole lives without encountering temperatures that warm, according to research published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. The antifreeze proteins that prevented the blood from completely freezing also bound itself to the ice crystals, keeping them from getting smaller, the scientists say. Lead researcher Paul Cziko tells the Christian Science Monitor that it's not clear whether the fish have evolved some way of dealing with the ice crystals in their bodies, or if the ice ends up killing them in the long term. "This shows that with every good evolutionary innovation, some potentially bad or unintended consequences come along with that," he says. "Evolution is a stepwise process. You take two steps forward, and take one step back." (Researchers recently solved the decades-old mystery of a quacking noise detected in Antarctic waters.)

answers: The West Coast sardine population was down 72% since 2006 per a fall assessment—the worst crash since the mid-20th century, and one with far-reaching implications, particularly since the steep decline is expected to continue. One of those implications: Ocean predators that depend on sardines may be starving, the Los Angeles Times reports: Researchers think 1,600 malnourished sea lion pups that washed up onshore in Southern California last year were born to nursing mothers whose milk quality was compromised after they had to turn from fatty sardines to other fish; brown pelicans—which also depend on sardines for food—are also suffering. Neither species can turn to anchovies as an alternative food source, as they normally would, because their numbers are also down. Fishermen, too, are affected; they're not allowed to catch as many sardines (harvest maximums have been dramatically cut)—and they often can't find any to catch (the LA Times follows one boat that caught zero fish in a 12-hour outing). So what's going on? Sardine populations often experience wild swings, booming when conditions are good and then dropping sharply when conditions shift. After the last bad collapse, which happened after a massive boom in the 1940s, sardine fishing was halted for 18 years beginning in the 1960s, and though the population bounced back in the 1980s, it was never the same. Scientists now, as then, aren't sure how to divide the blame between ocean conditions (the Pacific Decadal Oscillation, a climate cycle, has brought cold, sardine-unfriendly water to the area) and overfishing. Last month, Pew Charitable Trusts warned that dozens of species, including whales, sharks, dolphins, salmon, and tuna, could feel an impact.

Europe's best-known mummy, Ötzi, who died around 5300 years ago, had a difficult life, according to new research. He also suffered from an accident that caused him to lose one of his front teeth and may have had a stone lodged in his bread, leading to a broken tooth. The researchers suggest that the increase in cavities during the late Stone Age could be due to the uptick in starchy foods in human diets.

The researchers suggest that this finding may indicate that we have less control over arteriosclerosis than previously believed.

Ötzi's genome also placed him in the rare G2a haplogroup, which is linked to populations that migrated from the Middle East to Europe at the beginning of the Neolithic period. The researchers note that Ötzi's closest living genetic matches are currently found in Sardinia and other remote European populations.

The genome analysis also revealed that Ötzi had brown eyes, brown hair, and type O blood. He was also the first known carrier of Lyme disease, which has been plaguing humans for thousands of years. The researchers were unable to determine if Ötzi actually contracted the disease during his lifetime.

A rare species of snake, the Clarion nightsnake, which had been missing for almost 80 years, has been rediscovered on a remote Mexican island. The snake was first discovered by American naturalist William Beebe in 1936 on Clarion Island, one of the Revillagigedo Islands, off Mexico's Pacific coast. However, subsequent attempts to locate the snake failed, and it was assumed to be extinct or a labelling error.

They followed Beebe's original field notes and timed their expedition to replicate his steps. DNA analysis confirmed that the snake was indeed the Clarion nightsnake and was genetically distinct from other snakes found in mainland Mexico. The researchers also discovered that the snake's ancestors may have traveled to the island on a tree trunk that was washed ashore during a storm.

The Clarion nightsnake is now recognized as a distinct species and is found exclusively on Clarion Island. Its rediscovery is significant because of the fragility of island ecosystems and the potential loss of biodiversity. The National Museum of Natural History in Washington hailed Mulcahy's discovery as an important contribution to scientific knowledge and a reminder of the importance of historical data and museum collections.

The Clarion nightsnake is not the only rare species to have been rediscovered on the Revillagigedo Islands. The Socorro dove, which went extinct in its natural habitat, was reintroduced to the islands in the 1990s after being preserved in museum collections.
answers: The Clarion nightsnake is hard to spot, so hard to spot that for decades, the only sighting of the species native to one of Mexico's Revillagigedo Islands—the original sighting—was assumed to be a mistake. A joint US-Mexico team, however, managed to rediscover the species found by American naturalist William Beebe in 1936 by using his original field notes to retrace his steps and search for the nocturnal snake, which blends in with the island's rock formations, the AP reports. The expedition found 11 of the snakes, and DNA tests confirmed that the Clarion Island snake is a unique species, reports the BBC. The snake is related to snakes found on part of the Mexican coast more than 500 miles away, and researchers believe its ancestors may have arrived on a tree trunk washed out to sea long ago. Beebe returned from a visit to the island, located 400-plus miles off Mexico's Pacific coast, nearly 80 years ago with a snake preserved in a jar, but his sample had long been considered a labeling error and his find was largely struck from taxonomic registries. The National Museum of Natural History praised the team's work, describing the snake as the "only species ever to be discarded due to a presumed locality error." The rediscovery "is an incredible story of how scientists rely on historical data and museum collections to solve modern-day mysteries about biodiversity in the world we live in," the museum said in a statement.

Marburg virus, a rare and deadly hemorrhagic fever similar to Ebola, has resurfaced in Uganda and South Africa. The virus was first identified in Germany in 1967, and since then, there have been sporadic outbreaks in Africa. The latest outbreak in Uganda began in September 2022 when a 31-year-old man died of the disease in Kabale district. He had worked at a local hospital where several other cases were later identified. The Marburg virus is transmitted through contact with bodily fluids of infected individuals or contaminated surfaces. The incubation period is typically between 2-21 days. Symptoms include fever, headache, muscle aches, and vomiting, followed by hemorrhagic symptoms such as bleeding from the eyes, ears, and nose. The case-fatality rate is between 24% and 88%.

Upon identification of the outbreaks, health authorities in both countries implemented strict infection control measures and contacted the World Health Organization (WHO) for assistance. The WHO dispatched experts to both countries to help contain the spread of the virus.

In Uganda, 39 cases and 17 deaths have been reported as of October 2022. The outbreak was contained in Kabale district, and no new cases have been reported since mid-October. In South Africa, only one case has been confirmed, and the patient has since recovered.

Marburg virus is closely related to the Ebola virus, and outbreaks of both viruses have occurred in the same regions of Africa. However, Marburg virus is less contagious than Ebola and is not believed to spread easily between people who have not been in close contact with infected individuals.

The Marburg virus outbreaks in Uganda and South Africa serve as a reminder of the ongoing threat of hemorrhagic fevers in Africa. Health authorities are urging the public to practice good hygiene and to avoid contact with sick individuals to prevent the spread of the virus. answers: Humans were thought to be unique as a species in that we use both halves of our brains to "distinguish different aspects of sound," as Georgetown neuroscientist Stuart Washington puts it. In mustached bats—named based on the hair springing from the sides of their snouts, Animal Diversity Web explains—the right hemisphere's slower processing is used for sonar, "which relies on detecting small changes in frequency," says Washington, senior author of the study in Frontiers in Neuroscience. The left is used "to distinguish communication sounds from each other, because (the bats') communication sounds have rapid changes in frequency." All this is more than just a matter of interest: The findings could help study human language disorders, especially since some study techniques "can only be permitted in animals," Washington adds. Too 'fussy': David Leonhardt at the New York Times thinks "it's time to shed some of the fussy over-precision about the relationship between climate change and weather." answers: For more than 150 years, researchers have scratched their heads over a Civil War mystery—and now a Navy engineer says she's solved it. Rachel Lance has been diving deep into the 1864 sinking of the Confederate submarine HL Hunley, which mysteriously went down shortly after sinking the Union's USS Housatonic sloop with a torpedo, reports a Hakai Magazine article posted at Smithsonian.com. Over three years, Lance—a Duke grad student with no experience in forensics, no help from experts who'd long been on the case, and no access to the excavated sub itself—carried out what Gizmodo calls an "exhaustive … analysis" and finally arrived at a conclusion published in PLOS ONE: that the torpedo created blast waves that pierced the Hunley's hull and instantly killed the eight crew, whose skeletons were found intact during the sub's excavation near Charleston, SC, in 2000. Lance looked at other theories swirling around the Hunley's fate, including low oxygen or a bullet fired by the Housatonic that punctured the sub. She became obsessed, to the point she'd zone out during meals. "There was something viscerally terrifying about the fact that eight people died that night, and we had no idea how or why," she tells Hakai. Her injury biomechanics background finally led her to her shock wave theory. "When blast waves hit an air space, they slow down like a car hitting a wall," she says. "Except in this case, the wall is the surface of the lungs." A mini replica of the Hunley she dubbed the CSS Tiny and a series of test explosions in a rural pond helped her prove her theory, per CNN. Other researchers remain unconvinced, but Hakai says now Lance's theory is "their theory to disprove." More on her project here. (The Hunley looks a lot better these days.)

Teenage boys were the most likely to be killed but children as young as just a year old have been tortured and executed, reports the BBC. Bombing and shelling were the cause of most deaths and the report's authors have urged both sides to stop targeting civilians. More than 2.1 million refugees have now fled the conflict and the United Nations, which says this is the worst refugee crisis in a generation, warns that there could be 3.5 million refugees by the end of the year, reports the New York Times. To make matters even worse for internally displaced Syrians, al-Qaeda fighters have been making major gains in northern Syria in recent months, displacing more moderate opposition groups and imposing strict Islamic law in areas under their control, CNN finds. The jihadist groups are even more dangerous in Syria than they were in Iraq, and are "more likely to sustainably control territory, project power around the region, possibly sponsor global terrorist attacks, and catalyze a new generation of jihadist insurrection," a counterterrorism expert warns.

Texting while driving has long been a dangerous distraction,leading to numerous accidents and fatalities.Recently, there have been several legal developments that could potentially hold texters and even third parties accountable for distracted driving accidents.

In Pennsylvania, a judge ruled that two men who texted the driver of a car before an accident could be held liable for her actions.In the case,Gallagher v. Zywicki, the judge determined that the texters knew or should have known that the driver was operating a vehicle at the time of their communication, and their texts constituted a breach of duty. This ruling is believed to be the first of its kind in the United States.

Similarly, in New Jersey, a bill was introduced that would allow police to use a device called a "textalyzer" to determine if a driver was using their phone at the time of an accident. The device would be used to scan a phone for text messages, calls, and other data, potentially providing evidence of distracted driving.

Furthermore, a study by the American Automobile Association (AAA) found that distracted driving caused about 3,166 deaths in 2014, with texting being a major contributor. The study also revealed that drivers under the age of 20 were the most likely to text and drive.

In response to the growing concern over distracted driving, some states have taken action to ban handheld devices while driving, and others have implemented texting bans for all drivers.

Moreover, the use of social media apps while driving, such as Snapchat, has become a significant concern for safety advocates.In one case, a driver using the Snapchat filter "Speed Filter" while driving at over 100 miles per hour caused a fatal accident. The victim's family is now suing Snapchat for its role in the crash.

The legal landscape surrounding distracted driving is evolving, with potential liability extending beyond the driver to texters and even app developers.

As technology continues to advance, it is essential that drivers remain focused on the road and avoid distractions, including texting and using social media apps. The legal developments discussed above serve as a reminder of the potential consequences of distracted driving and the growing efforts to hold accountable those who contribute to this dangerous behavior.
answers: Court rulings in Pennsylvania and New Jersey are taking texting-while-driving laws down a new road, opening the door to not only holding the offending driver liable for a car accident, but perhaps also the person texting the driver, Consumerist reports. In neither case has anyone (yet) had to legally assume this burden: In the 2013 New Jersey appellate case, the "remote texter" was let off the hook because there wasn't enough evidence to show she knew her friend—who severely injured two people after slamming into their motorcycle—was driving when she texted him, the ABA Journal reports. And in the Pennsylvania case, the judge's ruling didn't hold responsible the two texters who were sending messages to the driver when she crashed into a motorcycle, killing that driver—it was simply determined the texters were fair game for the suit, per the Legal Intelligencer. But the fact that holding non-driving texters liable for car crashes is even being considered is starting to slowly impact the legal landscape on distracted driving. The New Jersey and Pennsylvania cases underscore the challenges in such cases. For instance, it's not enough to hold a texter liable simply because he or she texted a driver: Certain conditions must be met, such as knowing (or having good reason to believe) the driver would pick up the phone to check out texts while driving, as well as proving a "special relationship" exists between texter and recipient to influence the recipient picking up. But these kinds of cases, as well as other proposed crackdowns on car texters (including New York's controversial "textalyzer" bill), show the issue is being given heavier weight. "People often see distracted driving as a socially acceptable sin … an innocuous guilty pleasure in which everyone indulges," a University of South Carolina law professor tells Vocativ. "The same used to be true of drunk driving ... These legal developments could signal that a similar change in thinking is underway regarding distracted driving." (Jenny McCarthy's son called the cops for her texting-while-driving transgression.)

The researchers suggest that this "geek effect" could be due to a number of factors, including the father's age at the time of conception, the father's genetic makeup, or environmental influences. However, it also highlights the importance of considering the potential risks and limitations of delaying fatherhood, such as the increased risk of chromosomal abnormalities and other health issues.

answers: A new study suggests an upside for boys who have older dads: higher IQs. More specifically, they tend to score higher on what the researchers call the "geek index," reports the Guardian. And this is clearly seen as a positive: "If you look at who does well in life right now, it’s geeks," says Magdalena Janecka at King’s College London. The geek index, she explains, is determined by such factors as ability to focus, non-verbal IQ scores taken at age 12, and social aloofness. The latter trait may sound like a negative, but the BBC frames it as the boys not being overly concerned with fitting in. A mother's age appears to have no impact. The team studied more than 7,000 sets of twins in the UK. The average geek score for boys born to dads 25 or younger is 39. It goes up to 41 when dads had the child between 35 and 44, and jumps to 47 when dads were 50 or older. The impact was less pronounced on girls, and more pronounced when measuring science, tech, engineering, and math scores. Kids born to fathers 50 or older were 32% more likely to earn at least two A's on standardized tests than children born to men aged under 25, the researchers report in Translational Psychiatry. They calculate that 57% of the geek index score is inherited, with possible overlap between genes that contribute to a high geek score and to autism. “Our primary hypothesis is that higher levels of those ‘geeky’ traits in offspring of older men are mainly due is due to characteristics of the fathers themselves," Janecka tells Newsweek. "Men who decide to delay fatherhood often do so due to their extended career and educational pursuits, and likely themselves display higher levels of ‘geekiness.’” (Younger fathers are also likelier to die younger.)
